items.title: Comparative study on sea-level rise in the Yangtze River Estuary and Red River Estuary in the recent 30 years
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 15 October 2025

Comparative study on sea-level rise in the Yangtze River Estuary and Red River Estuary in the recent 30 years
                    Wenjing Xue1, Lulu Qiao1,2, Sichen Zhang1, Yi Zhong3, Xiaoyong Duan4, Ping Yin4 & …Jian Liu4 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 35938 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate changeOcean sciences

AbstractSea-level rise with its impacts on coastal areas has become one of the most important topics. The Yangtze River Estuary (YRE) and Red River Estuary (RRE) are the most sensitive regions to climate change but locating in temperate and subtropical regions of Asia, respectively. However, there is few comparative studies between sea level change in estuaries affected by different climatic and dynamic conditions. Using long-term satellite altimetry data combined with sea surface temperature (SST) and wind field data, this study analyzed temporal variations of sea level anomaly (SLA) and its controlling factors. The SLA in these two estuaries has shown a significant increase, with the rate in the RRE (3.6 mm/yr) being slightly higher than that in the YRE (3.4 mm/yr). Frequency spectra analysis indicated a remarkable annual, seasonal (about 4-month cycles) and about 2-month signals in the YRE. Moreover, annual and semi-annual signals were founded in the RRE. The highest SLA in these two estuaries are mostly occurring in October. SLA variations in the YRE are influenced by both SST and local wind, whereas that in the RRE are mainly affected by SST. Interestingly, the different lag time of SLA to SST in two estuaries is related to water depth. Furthermore, the maximum SLA is predicted to reach 0.47 m in the YRE and 0.41 m in the RRE for the next 10 years (2023–2032), respectively. This study aims to understand the controlling mechanism of SLA changes in estuaries in different geographical locations.

IntroductionSea-level rise (SLR) is one of the consequences of global climate change, directly affecting production, social and economic development in coastal areas1,2,3. Rising sea levels will submerge and erode coastal lowlands, induce groundwater pollution, increase the salinity of estuarine water, and damage ecosystems3,4,5,6,7,8. Hence, governments and scientists have conducted extensive studies on global and coastal sea level changes. According to the Fifth Assessment Reports (AR5) published by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), it has been projected that the global mean sea level is gradually rising and accelerating, with rates of 1.3 mm/yr (1901–1971), 1.9 mm/yr (1971–2006), 3.2 mm/yr (1993–2015), and 3.7 mm/yr (2006–2018)1. However, sea level does not rise uniformly in different areas.The Yangtze River and Red River are the longest rivers in China and northern Vietnam, respectively, with a tremendous amount of discharge flowing into the East China Sea and South China Sea9,10. Furthermore, the YRE and RRE are typical estuaries in temperate and subtropical regions of Asia, and are affected by different climatic and dynamic conditions. They will be good samples to compare and analyze the trends of sea level variations and their controlling mechanisms in different areas. In addition, these two estuaries exhibit low-lying terrain, which makes them highly vulnerable to the impacts of SLR. This is mainly manifested in the destruction of groundwater resources, increased severity of storm surges, flooding, and saltwater intrusion, intensified coastal erosion, and the loss of mudflats and wetlands11,12,13,14.Previous studies have calculated and analyzed the sea level variations along the coastal areas of China and Vietnam, which indicate that sea levels are rising with an accelerating rate15,16,17. However, due to differences in calculation methods and data record lengths, the estimated sea level rates may vary. Based on long-term tide gauge observations, the rising rates of sea level along the coast of China were approximately 2.4 mm/yr (1960–2020), 3.4 mm/yr (1980–2020), and 3.9 mm/yr (1993–2020)18. Qu et al.17 accounted for vertical land movement and estimated the SLR rates to be about 3.2 ± 1.1 mm/yr (1993–2016) and 2.9 ± 0.8 mm/yr (1993–2016). Mu et al.19 reconstructed the rise of sea level along the coast of China and found that the rate was approximately 3.12 mm/yr during 1980–2022, noting that the rising rate after 1980 was three times higher than before. The rate of rising sea level in the coastal Vietnam, calculated using altimeter data during 1993–2015, was 3.2 mm/yr20. These rates were found to be higher than the corresponding global mean sea level during the same periods1. The results revealed that the sea level variation cycle exhibited remarkable oscillatory signals with periods of annual, semi-annual and seasonal scales21,22. Although there have been relevant studies on SLA in the two major coastal zones, there are few studies on SLA changes in the estuaries, which are special coastal zone sensitive to global warming. There are also few studies on the different responses of estuaries in different geographical locations to global changes.The sea level anomaly (SLA) can be affected by spatial changes in winds, air-sea heat budget, atmospheric pressure loading, ice melting, tectonic subsidence or uplift and thermo-steric effects2,15,16,17. Previous studies have shown that SLA is influenced by sea surface temperature (SST) and wind in these two estuaries15,16,18,23. According to Ishii et al.24, thermal expansion averaged over all longitudes between 60°S and 60°N accounts for almost 50% of SLR during the past decade. Since the 1980s, however, the contribution of ocean thermal expansion to SLR has generally exhibited a decreasing trend, accounting for about 38.6% during 2006–201825. Using oceanic and atmospheric reanalysis dataset and the Regional Ocean Modeling System, Cai et al.26 investigated the response of sea surface height in the East China Sea to the East Asian climatic jump in 1976/1777. The results indicate that two anomalous anti-cyclonic oceanic currents appeared in the Yellow Sea and three anomalous oceanic currents appeared in the East China Sea, which caused water bodies to be transported toward the Yellow Sea, resulting in obviously positive SLA in these areas. Land subsidence due to rapid urbanization and groundwater extraction has also been considered an important factor contributing to SLR since the 1990s27,28,29. Moreover, wind fields cause SLR or sea-level decline by driving sea water transport, which is particularly significant in coastal areas26,30. For estuarine areas, as the intersection of land and ocean, sea level variations are also affected by river discharge31.The sea level variation cycle was analyzed through various methods, including the least squares method, fast Fourier Transform, Continuous Wavelet Transform, and Empirical Orthogonal Function (EOF) methods. Furthermore, researchers have tried to accurately predict future global or regional SLR32,33,34. The Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (SARIMA) model is one of the time series prediction and analysis methods, and is widely used in various domains, including medicine, economics and ecology35,36. The SARIMA model can be used for short-term prediction of univariate, stationary or differenced stationary time series with fixed periods. If the dataset is a non-stationary sequence, differencing and seasonal differencing are used to remove non-stationary from the time series. However, this model is sensitive to missing values, which can affect its performance37,38.This work aims to conduct a comparative study of sea level changes and their controlling mechanisms under different climatic and dynamic conditions, taking the YRE and RRE as examples. The averaged values in the areas of 31°–32°N, 121.5°–122.5°E and 18°–22°N, 105°–108°E, respectively, are used to represent the YRE and RRE (Fig. 1). Based on long-term satellite altimetry data from 1993 to 2022, the variability of SLA, its long-term trends, and controlling mechanisms in these two estuaries were analyzed in this paper. Meanwhile, we quantitatively clarified the relationships between SLA and SST, as well as SLA and wind speed with its u and v components, respectively. Moreover, land subsidence was considered to predict SLR in these two estuaries.Fig. 1Sketch map (a) of the Yangtze River Estuary (YRE) (b) and Red River Estuary (RRE) (c) with their adjacent coastal regions. The red squares in the images represent the domain used to calculate the area-averaged sea level anomaly (SLA), sea surface temperature (SST), and wind speed. Contours indicate the water depth. The purple solid dots indicate the tide gauge stations at Lvsi (China) and Hondau (Vietnam), respectively.Full size imageResultsAnnual variations of SLR in these two estuariesThe area-averaged (the areas were shown in Fig. 1) monthly altimetry SLA of coastal areas in the two estuaries was calculated to analyze the long-term temporal variabilities of SLA during 1993–2022. As shown in Fig. 2, the trends of SLA curves showed significant increases with rates of 3.4 mm/yr and 3.6 mm/yr in the YRE and RRE, respectively. The multi-year average SLA in the YRE has been 0.04 m since 1993. Moreover, it is evident that rate of SLR during 2009–2022 (4.7 mm/yr) was obviously faster than that during 1993–2008 (3.7 mm/yr) in the YRE. Similarly, the multi-year average SLA was also 0.04 m in the RRE and the rate of SLR in 2010–2022 (5.2 mm/yr) was faster than that in 1993–2009 (3.4 mm/yr). Computed over one-year-long moving windows, a slowdown period (1999–2005) was observed in the YRE (Fig. 2a). It is observed that most of the years experienced significant fluctuations in the RRE (Fig. 2b), except during 2001 to 2004, 2015 to 2019.Fig. 2The variance envelope and annual variations of SLA in the (a) YRE and (b) RRE, respectively. The yellow background indicates SLA variance envelope. The blue bar indicates the monthly-SLA. The purple solid line and the dotted line indicate the variations of the annual-SLA and its trend, respectively.Full size imageFurthermore, there were three remarkable SLA peaks in September 2022, October 2021 and October 2016, which were 0.39 m, 0.34 m and 0.32 m. The SLA exhibited significantly lower values, such as − 0.19 m, − 0.18 m and − 0.17 m in March 2018, March 1996, March 2005 in the YRE (Fig. 2a). Although the low SLA values didn’t change significantly, the high SLA values increased rapidly over time in the YRE. In addition, the extreme highest and lowest SLA values in the RRE were 0.39 m in October 2020 and − 0.18 m in July 1995, respectively (Fig. 2b). In contrast to the YRE, the change of high SLA values in the RRE were not very severe, except October 2020, while the low values were gradually increasing.The frequency spectra analysis provides a more effective way to identify signals by decomposing the raw data into time domains synchronously. The power spectra of the SLA series exhibited prominent peaks at about 11.5–12.5 months, 3.9–4.1 months, and 2.2 months in the YRE (Fig. 3a), respectively, all of which were above the 95% confidence level (CL), with the last two peaks being less significant than the first one. In addition, similar features with peaks at about 11.5–12.5 months and 5.9–6.1 months above the 95% CL in the RRE (Fig. 3b) were displayed, respectively. Analysis of satellite altimeter results shows that sea-level change has a clear inter-annual signal with an approximately 1-year cycle in the two estuaries. In addition, seasonal signal (about 4-month cycle) and 2-month cycles occurred in the YRE, while a semi-annual signal occurred in the RRE. This indicates that four-season variation is much more obvious in the northern China Seas, whereas the half-year change characterized by wet and dry seasons is more dominant in the southern seas.Fig. 3Power spectra of SLA in the (a) YRE and (b) RRE, respectively. The blue solid line represents the power spectra of SLA, and the red dotted line represents the 95% confidence level (CL).Full size imageSummer and winter variations of SLR in these two estuariesTo analyze the seasonal variabilities of the altimetry SLA during recent years (1993–2022), January and July were taken as representative months for winter and summer, respectively. Generally, the SLA exhibited higher values in summer than in winter, except in 2000, 2001, 2006, 2008, 2013, 2016, 2019, 2021, and 2022 in the YRE (Fig. 4a). Conversely, the opposite situation prevailed in the RRE where SLA consistently showed higher values in winter (Fig. 4b). Overall, SLA variations in the two estuaries both displayed an obvious increasing trend (Fig. 4a,b), whether in winter or summer. The rate of SLR was significantly faster in winter than in summer (average of 3.7 mm/yr versus 2.0 mm/yr) in the YRE (Fig. 4a), while it was slightly faster in summer than in winter (average of 4.2 mm/yr versus 3.9 mm/yr) in the RRE (Fig. 4b).Fig. 4The variabilities of SLA in summer and winter in the (a) YRE and (b) RRE, respectively. The red and blue lines represent the variations of monthly SLA in summer and winter, respectively.Full size imageSea level rise in these two estuaries in the futureIt is widely accepted that sea level will continue to rise in the future. The SARIMA model was introduced in the previous section. In order to establish the model, altimetry SLA data from 1993 to 2013 were used as the training set. The remaining data (2014–2022) were used as the test set to evaluate the model’s performance in terms of fitting and prediction. Since the accuracy of model predictions tends to decrease over time, SLA for the next 10 years (2023–2032) was predicted in the two estuaries.Based on the results of the testing group, the predicted values were compared to the actual SLA. The RMSE was 0.06 m in the YRE and 0.04 m in the RRE, respectively, indicating that the models are reliable and can be utilized. The results showed that the maximum SLA is predicted to increase, reaching 0.46 m in the YRE and 0.40 m in the RRE (Fig. 5), respectively. Land subsidence is likely associated with long-term tectonic movements and anthropogenic pressure. However, human activities have been documented as the primary causes of surface subsidence in these two regions27,28,39. Based on time-series Interferometric synthetic aperture radar (InSAR) technology, the average subsidence rate in Shanghai was less than 10 mm/yr from 2000 to 2012 and was 5.6 mm/yr in 201229. Land subsidence is best controlled in the YRE. This has been achieved by reducing groundwater withdraw and implementing artificial recharge of the aquifer systems. Similarly, using Sentineal-1A InSAR data, the most recent land surface deformation in Hanoi was also about 5 mm/yr over 2016–202028. Thus, the rate of land subsidence was considered into the prediction of future SLA changes. Consequently, the maximum SLA is predicted to increase, reaching 0.47 m in the YRE and 0.41 m in the RRE, respectively. The inconsistency of specific values with other conclusions can be attributed to differences in prediction time and methods. However, it is important to note that the magnitude of the predicted SLA remained consistent.Fig. 5Comparison of satellite-measured SLA and predicted SLA in the (a) YRE and (b) RRE, respectively. The blue lines indicate the real SLA. The red lines indicate the medium of predicted SLA. The green areas indicate the upper and lower limits of predicted SLA.Full size imageDiscussionLong-term satellite data on water temperature can be used to indicate changes in ocean steric level. The area-averaged SST (the areas were shown in Fig. 1) was calculated in the two estuaries. Although the 20-year period (2003–2022) may be considered relatively brief for a comprehensive analysis of SST effects on SLA changes, it is still possible to explore the potential correlation between their annual variations.The correlation coefficient between SLA and SST for the same month was calculated. However, contrary to our expectation, no such good relationships were found in the two estuaries (R2 = 0.27 in the YRE and R2 = 0.09 in the RRE) (Fig. 6). Considering it takes time for SST to work on SLA variations, we further conducted the correlation coefficients between SLA and SST with several months ahead. The correlation coefficients fluctuated as the number of months increased (Fig. 6). Interestingly, it reached a maximum when cumulative SST with 2-month ahead in the YRE (R2 = 0.64) and 6-month ahead in the RRE (R2 = 0.71), respectively.Fig. 6The correlation coefficients between SLA and SST, SLA and wind with the same month, and one to 6 months ahead in the (a) YRE and (b) RRE, respectively. The red, blue, yellow, and green bars show the correlation coefficients between SLA and SST, SLA and W-wind speed, SLA and U-wind speed, and SLA and V-wind speed, respectively.Full size imageIn addition, SLA exhibited a highly significant positive correlation with 2-month and 6-month ahead SST in the two estuaries. This correlation suggests that SLA is more vulnerable to the impacts of SST. The variation of time lag can potentially be attributed to differences in water depth in the two estuaries. The depth in the RRE (0–40 m) is deeper than that in the YRE (0–20 m), resulting in a longer time for heating the entire water body.The cumulative SST from May to June was always higher than that from November to December (Fig. 7a), which cannot explain why SLA in winter was higher than in summer in certain years, indicating that SLA was also influenced by other factors in the YRE. Thus, the effect of wind is discussed later. As mentioned in Fig. 4, SLA was higher in winter than in summer in the RRE. SLA in summer was mainly affected by the cumulative SST from January to June, while SLA in winter was affected by the cumulative SST from July to December in the RRE. The value of the latter SST was higher than the former (Fig. 7b), which could partly explain the fact that SLA was higher in winter than in summer in the RRE.Fig. 7The variations of SLA and SST with the same month, 2-month ahead in the (a) YRE and 6-month ahead in the (b) RRE. The blue bars indicate the climatology SLA. The black solid lines indicate the SST with the same month. The orange dotted lines indicate the cumulative SST with 2-month ahead in the (a) YRE and 6-month ahead averaged in the (b) RRE, respectively.Full size imageThe variations in sea water temperature from the surface to bottom layers exhibited an approximately similar trend in the two areas (Fig. 8), with temperatures warming from winter to summer and cooling from the surface layer to the bottom. However, the duration of high SST in the RRE (Fig. 8b) was longer than in the YRE (Fig. 8a). It should be noted that the warming process of the bottom layer lagged behind the surface by 2 and 4 months in the YRE and RRE, respectively. This means that the warming of the entire water body exhibits a phase lag relative to SST. Therefore, the response of SLA related to the thermal expansion effect was delayed to SST.Fig. 8The climatology seawater temperature at each layer from the surface to bottom in the (a) YRE and in the (b) RRE, respectively. The red and black solid lines indicate the surface and bottom temperature.Full size imageSLA is not only related to SST but is also influenced by wind, particularly in the coastal areas. Cai et al.3 suggested that the monsoon variation was likely to play an important role in the changes of SLA in the East China Seas and its adjacent areas. In order to examine the impact of the wind field on SLA, the correlation coefficients between SLA and wind speed (W-wind) (the areas were shown in Fig. 1) including the zonal component of wind (U-wind) speed and the meridional component of wind (V-wind) speed in the same month and accumulated speeds several months ahead were also calculated, respectively.In the YRE, SLA had a better correlation with V-wind speed, reaching a maximum (R2 = 0.58) when V-wind speed was accumulated over 6-month (Fig. 6a). However, there was little correlation between SLA and U-wind speed. Meanwhile, the correlations of SLA with W-wind speed, U-wind speed, and V-wind speed in the RRE were generally not better than that in the YRE, except for V-wind speed in the same month (Fig. 6b). The water depth in the YRE is relatively shallow, where water movement is more susceptible to wind forcing. In contrast, the water depth in the RRE is deeper than that in the YRE, and baroclinic current also play a significant role in water transport. Consequently, the SLA in the YRE exhibits a stronger relationship with the wind field than that in the RRE.In addition, the higher cumulative V-wind speed with 6-month ahead, the greater increase (or decrease) of SLA under the southerly (northerly) wind. This indicates that sustained southerly wind can result in water volume accumulation and rising sea levels in the YRE. This is primarily due to the restraining effect of the terrain. On the contrary, northerly wind may cause lower SLA in the YRE. To verify this viewpoint, climatological averaged current flux data during 2011–2020 in the YRE were calculated. During August to November, the cumulative water flux with 6-month ahead showed a positive value, which remained consistent with southerly wind. This indicated northward water transport by the southerly wind, which caused the rising sea levels (Fig. 9a). Similarly, southward water transport driven by northerly wind was responsible for the negative SLA from January to April. However, SLA remained at a high level in June and July, even when cumulative V-wind with 6-month ahead was negative. The relatively high SST during these 2 months suggests that SLA may be more vulnerable to SST under higher SST conditions.Fig. 9The variations of SLA, wind and current flux in the (a) YRE and (b) RRE, respectively. The blue bars indicate the climatology SLA. The orange and green solid lines indicate the cumulative V-wind with 6-month ahead and cumulative U-wind with 4-month ahead in the YRE, as shown in Fig. 5a, and the cumulative V-wind with the same month and cumulative U-wind with 6-month ahead in the RRE, as shown in Fig. 5b, respectively. The black solid line indicates the cumulative current flux with 6-month ahead in the YRE.Full size imageIn contrast to the YRE, SLA exhibited relatively high values under the northerly wind (V-wind speed was negative) in the RRE (Fig. 9b), such as October, November and December. Conversely, SLA was negative, coinciding with strong southerly wind speeds from April to August, especially in June. Combined with the smaller correlation coefficients, this indicates that SLA changes in the RRE was mainly affected by SST.The Yangtze River accounts for the largest source of freshwater into the West Pacific. Annually, it discharges 9.24 × 1011 m3 of freshwater into the Yellow and East China Seas, and the fluvial flow rate can reach 50,000 to 60,000 m3/s in summer9. The annual water discharge at the Son Tay station in the Red River is about 3577 m3/s over the period from 1960 to 200810. Therefore, the impact of discharge on SLA could not be ignored. Although both water discharge and SLA exhibit half-year periodicities, a direct correlation is not consistently observed. The discharge of the Yangtze River and Red River reaches its peak in July or August. However, the highest SLA value in these two estuaries generally delay this time, mostly occurring in October. The high-discharge months do not consistently correlate with a subsequent increase in the YRE (Fig. 10a). In the RRE, the close relationship between them even cannot be found at all (Fig. 10b).Fig. 10The variations of the SLA and water discharge at the (a) Datong station in the YRE and (b) Son Tay station in the RRE. The blue and red solid lines indicate the monthly SLA and water discharge, respectively.Full size imageLi et al.40, based on 48 saltwater intrusion events in the YRE during 2009–2018, concluded that these events exhibit distinct seasonal patterns. In 2022, seven saltwater intrusion events occurred in the YRE, with one event starting on September 20th and lasting for 28 days. During this period, coinciding with the astronomical high tide, the maximum chloride ion concentration reached 2176 mg/L, affecting the drinking water for coastal residents as well as fisheries and aquaculture41. High storm surges coinciding with high tides led to extensive overtopping of sea dikes, and the seawater penetrated inland 3–4 km in the RRE. Flash floods following Typhoon Damrey destroyed at least 1194 houses and submerged and damaged more than 1.3 × 105 hectares of rice fields11. Moreover, unprotected coastline erosion occurs at a rate of about 10–20 m/yr, and the shoreline has retreated 3 km in Vietnam42. Mangrove forests in the tropical and semi-tropical areas are critical for shoreline stabilization and are increasingly threatened by prolonged inundation and salinization43. Approximately 1091 ha of mangrove forest was converted into aquaculture ponds during 2000–2006 in the interior of the Red River Delta, which poses not only environmental threats but also socioeconomic risks to local communities44.In conclusion, this work compares the SLA changes during 1993–2022 between the typical estuaries in the temperate and subtropical areas. The YRE and RRE are selected as two samples with different climatic and dynamic conditions, and the study is based on long-term satellite altimetry data, combined with SST and wind field data. The SLA in these two estuaries has shown a significant increase, with the rate in the RRE (3.6 mm/yr) being slightly higher than that in the YRE (3.4 mm/yr). Furthermore, the SARIMA method was employed to incorporate the factor of land subsidence to predict SLA for 2022–2032. The results indicate that the maximum SLA is projected to reach 0.47 m in the YRE and 0.41 m in the RRE, respectively.This study found that different reasons caused the SLA variations in these two estuaries. In the YRE, SLA was influenced by both SST and wind field, due to the thermal expansion of seawater and oceanic circulation. In contrast, SLA change in the RRE was mainly affected by SST, with little relationship to the wind field. This is because water transport in the RRE is influenced not only by wind forcing but also by baroclinic current. Furthermore, the correlation reached a maximum when the cumulative SST with 2-month ahead in the YRE and 6-month ahead in the RRE, respectively. The longer phase lag in the RRE compared to the YRE is also attributed to its deeper water depth. Although the study areas are located in the estuaries, it was found that the highest SLA values usually occur in October in these two estuaries, rather than in July or August with huge discharge.MethodsData sourceThe archiving, validation and interpretation of satellite oceanographic (AVISO) includes global sea surface height products such as gridded SLA (compared to the average value during 1993–2012). The spatial resolution of the AVISO dataset is 0.25°. This data was downloaded from https://resources.marine.copernicus.eu/products. The monthly SST product, with a spatial resolution of ~ 9 km from July 2002 to 2022, was provided by MODIS-Aqua (http://oceancolor.gsfc.nasa.gov). The Climate Forecast System Reanalysis (CFSR) ocean surface wind data was used to analyze the influence of wind field on SLA variations. This is the 3rd generation global reanalysis product developed by National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP). The spatial resolution of the CFSR dataset is approximately 0.3° prior to 2011 and 0.2° after 2011, respectively. The CFSR dataset was available at https://climatedataguide.ucar.edu/climate-data/climate-forecast-system-reanalysis-cfsr. The climatology temperature dataset from 1993 to 2016 is provided by the European Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMESE). The spatial resolution of the CMESE dataset is 1/12°. This data was downloaded from https://resources.marine.copernicus.eu. The Permanent service for mean sea level is the global data bank for long-term sea-level information from tide gauges45. In this study, Lvsi and Hondau tidal gauge stations were selected to validate the applicability of satellite-derived SLA data. The results indicate that the correlation coefficients between SLA from tidal gauges and satellite altimetry were 0.75 and 0.73 in the Lvsi and Hondau stations, respectively (Fig. 11). The discharge of the Yangtze River was obtained from Changjiang Sediment Bulletin. The discharge of the Red River was collected from reference10.Fig. 11Comparison of SLA from satellite altimetry and tidal gauge stations in the Lvsi and Hondau, respectively.Full size imageAnalysis methodsSpectral analysis is widely employed in analyzing complex signal change on long-term timescales46,47,48. It helps determine the signal frequency range and provides information into the energy density spectrum. In this paper, spectral analysis was applied to visualize the energy distribution of sea level changes in the frequency domain.Time series forecasting is a crucial aspect in various domains, including medicine, economic and ecology36,37,38. Consequently, researchers have dedicated significant efforts over many years to develop suitable models. Various models have been proposed successively in the literature, including the well-known Autoregressive Moving Average (ARMA), Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA), and Autoregressive Fractionally Integrated Moving Average (ARFIMA) models, etc. The seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (SARIMA) model is a generalization of the ARIMA model, derived from the Box-Jenkins principle. As a result, SARIMA models are broadly known as Box-Jenkins models35. The model is generally termed as the SARIMA (p, d, q) × (P, D, Q)s, where (p, d, q) is the non-seasonal part and (P, D, Q)s is the seasonal part of the model, respectively. The mathematical formulation of the model is given below:$$\upvarphi _{\text{p}} ({\text{B}})\Phi _{{\text{p}}} ({\text{B}}^{{\text{s}}} )(1 - {\text{B}})^{{\text{d}}} (1 - {\text{B}}^{{\text{s}}} )^{{\text{D}}} {\text{y}}_{{\text{t}}} = \uptheta _{{\text{q}}} ({\text{B}})\Theta _{{\text{Q}}} ({\text{B}}^{{\text{s}}} ){\text{u}}_{{\text{t}}}$$
                    (1)
                where p = non-seasonal autoregressive (AR) order, d = non-seasonal differencing, q = non-seasonal moving average (MA) order, P = seasonal AR order, D = seasonal differencing, Q = seasonal MA order, and s = seasonal difference step (for monthly time series, s = 12). Although model parameters can be determined using auto-correlation function and partial auto-correlation function, it usually causes large errors. Therefore, a grid search method was adopted, which involves traversing different parameters combinations, developing a new model for each set, and evaluating the overall performance. The final model was specified as SARIMA (1, 1, 1) × (1, 0, 1)12.A numerical simulation was performed using an Unstructured Grid, Finite-Volume Community Ocean Model (FVCOM)49,50. This model has been successfully applied to investigations of estuaries, coasts and adjacent shelf seas51. The simulation area covered the entire East China Sea. The horizontal resolution of the mesh varied from approximately 1–2.5 km in the YRE. In vertical, the water depth was divided into 20 uniform sigma layers. The topography data used in the simulation was based on the China Marine Chart database and the ETOPO1 data. In the simulation, the model was forced by tidal forcing and mean flow at the open boundary. Eight tidal constituents (M2, S2, O1, Q1, K1, P1, K2, and N2) were obtained from NAO99 tide model52. Water and sediment discharges of the Yangtze River and Yellow River were obtained from the Bulletin of Chinese River Sediment. Additionally, sea surface height, water temperature, and salinity were considered for the model forcing, which were derived from the Simple Ocean Data Assimilation (SODA) climatological data. The simulated water level and current velocity agreed well with the observations. Further detailed description and model validation can be found from Zhong et al.53.Based on the model results of currents, climatological averaged current flux (V) during 2011–2020 was calculated. Mathematically, the calculation can be written as follows:$$\text{V} = \sum {\text{v}}_{\text{i}}{{\text{A}}}_{\text{i}}\text{=}\iint {\text{v}}{\text{dA}}$$
                    (2)
                where vi is the flow velocity of layer i, and Ai is the area of layer i. The flux unit is Sv (106 m3/s). The climatological current flux for each month was calculated during 2011–2020. The flux at the cross-section, positioned at 32°N and covering a longitude range of 121–123°E, was utilized to analyze the influence of the wind field on SLA variation in the YRE.

Data availability
              
              The sea level anomaly (SLA) data analyzed during the current study is available in the Archiving, Validation and Interpretation of Satellite Oceanographic (AVISO) at https://resources.marine.copernicus.eu/products. The monthly sea surface temperature (SST) data is available in the MODIS-Aqua at http://oceancolor.gsfc.nasa.gov. The wind field data is available in the Climate Forecast System Reanalysis (CFSR) at https://climatedataguide.ucar.edu/climate-data/climate-forecast-system-reanalysis-cfsr. The climatology temperature dataset is available in the European Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMESE) at https://resources.marine.copernicus.eu. The datasets used during the current study available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

items.title: Sulle tracce del cervo sardo
items.description:
Una puntata ricca di voci quella di ottobre del podcast WWF "Viaggio in Oasi da Monte Arcosu
The post Sulle tracce del cervo sardo appeared first on W
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il Giaguaro In evidenza Adotta una specie Una nuova puntata del podcast WWF ci porta a Monte Arcosu, in Sardegna “Un posto fantastico, è la prima volta che raggiungo queste vallate incredibili, mi sto già innamorando di questa riserva. Spero di tornare l’anno prossimo” (Alessandro, volontario)“40 anni che vengo qui, e ogni volta che vedo un cervo è la stessa emozione della prima volta” (Antonello, volontario)“Avevo sentito dire che era l’Oasi più bella del WWF Italia e penso di averne capito il motivo “ (Edoardo Nevola, WWF Italia)“Quando abbiamo iniziato i censimenti, nel 1989, il numero dei cervi sardi era decisamente più basso. L’anno scorso abbiamo toccato quota 900” (Giovanni Paulis, Oasi WWF Monte Arcosu). Una puntata ricca di voci quella di ottobre del podcast WWF “Viaggio in Oasi da Monte Arcosu: Marco Galaverni, direttore Oasi WWF Italia ci spiega i meccanismi alla base del corteggiamento e della riproduzione del cervo, mentre dalla voce di Fulco Pratesi, il fondatore del WWF scomparso il primo marzo scorso, un racconto commovente di come avvenne la nascita dell’Oasi, nel 1985 dopo una straordinaria campagna di raccolta fondi lanciata per salvare il cervo sardo dall’estinzione. Tanti i volontari e gli appassionati (circa 150 nei 2 giorni del censimento) che hanno supportato il WWF in questa avventura. Sulle tracce del cervo sardo Ascolta la puntata del podcast WWF dedicata a Monte Arcosu e al censimento del cervo sardo Ascolta il podcast Monte Arcosu Il complesso forestale Monte Arcosu-Piscinamanna costituisce la foresta di macchia mediterranea più estesa dell’intero bacino del Mediterraneo. L’Oasi di Monte Arcosu si trova all’interno di una Zona Speciale di Conservazione (ITB041105) nei Comuni di Uta, Assemini e Siliqua… Scopri di più

items.title: Penso in verde, il nuovo spazio didattico
items.description:
Al via la nuova rubrica insieme a Mondadori Education per promuovere la sostenibilità ambientale divertendosi
The post Penso in verde, il nuovo spazio
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il Giaguaro In evidenza Adotta una specie Il nuovo spazio didattico realizzato insieme a Mondadori Education La natura ha bisogno del nostro impegno e insegnare ai bambini a prendersene cura è un compito importante. “Penso in verde” è il nuovo spazio didattico, nato dalla collaborazione fra WWF Italia e Mondadori Education, ricco di idee e attività per avvicinare i bambini e le bambine della scuola primaria al tema sostenibilità ambientale, in modo semplice, divertente e consapevole. Un viaggio divertente e curioso nel mondo della sostenibilità dove, attraverso quattro video pillole, sarà possibile scoprire altrettanti segreti di biodiversità sugli alberi, l’orso gentile, le chiacchiere tra delfini, e il cibo che fa bene al pianeta. Per educare giovani cittadini consapevoli e responsabili, pronti a fare la differenza e preservare la nostra casa comune. “Penso in verde” è un nuovo modo di imparare facendo esperienze, uno strumento per imparare facendo esperienze: la natura ha bisogno di tutto il nostro impegno e insegnare alle giovani generazioni a prendersi cura del mondo è un compito importante, nel quale WWF Italia e Mondadori Education possono accompagnarli. Tutti i video Guarda le video pillole e scopri di più Guarda Gli altri ambiti della collaborazione Nell’ambito della collaborazione fra WWF e Mondadori Education, sono stati realizzati anche due webinar, pubblicati uno il 20 gennaio e l’altro il 3 febbraio 2025 e visibili su Youtube dal titolo “Biodiversità è normalità” e “I servizi ecosistemici e un libro per le Vacanze speciali, dedicato all’ educazione ambientale consente agli studenti di “ripassare” nella natura. A questi contenuti si aggiungono i taccuini, uno dedicato ad ogni stagione.  Materiali originali pronti per essere stampati dalle insegnanti e completati dagli alunni. Tutti i taccuini si adattano alle diverse classi della scuola primaria perché consentono un lavoro a differenti livelli e sono stati progettati in conformità con le nuove Linee guida per l’insegnamento dell’educazione civica: stimoleranno, infatti, un confronto in classe basato su esperienze dirette. Per ogni taccuino si trova anche una guida per l’insegnante, con suggerimenti e proposte integrative. Scopri di più su One Planet School La rubrica "Penso Verde" Vai Educazione Lavoriamo da anni per educare tutti alla cultura della sostenibilità, in particolare le giovani generazioni Scopri di più

items.title: Giretto d’Italia: Padova vince la maglia rosa della mobilità attiva
items.description: Oltre 50 tra comuni e aziende hanno preso parte al nostro campionato urbano della mobilità sostenibile che promuovere gli spostamenti casa-lavoro e c
items.body:
13 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

13 Ottobre 2025

Economia e sostenibilità

Mobilità

Giretto d’Italia: Padova vince la maglia rosa della mobilità attiva

13 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

13 Ottobre 2025

Economia e sostenibilità

Mobilità

Oltre 50 tra comuni e aziende hanno preso parte al nostro campionato urbano della mobilità sostenibile che promuovere gli spostamenti casa-lavoro e casa-scuola in bici. 
Lo sviluppo della mobilità sostenibile trova terreno fertile nelle aree urbane e nei contesti aziendali che investono in sicurezza, infrastrutture e servizi, con evidenti differenze tra Nord e Sud Italia.
Non lascia dubbi il bilancio della XV edizione di Giretto d’Italia  – il nostro campionato urbano della mobilità attiva organizzato nella Settimana Europea della Mobilità Sostenibile con il sostegno di Euromobility – che da quindici anni scatta un’istantanea delle abitudini di spostamento legate alla mobilità attiva nei capoluoghi del Paese cercando di comprendere come varia il modal share. Rivolto a cittadini, studenti e lavoratori (anche smart worker) ha l’obiettivo di promuovere gli spostamenti casa-lavoro e/o casa-scuola in bici o con l’utilizzo di mezzi di micromobilità elettrica. Per partecipare basta recarsi al lavoro o a scuola utilizzando un mezzo trasporto attivo e non inquinante passando in uno dei check point previsti nelle città aderenti, nella fascia oraria dedicata al monitoraggio. A vincere la sfida è la città/azienda che totalizza il maggior numero di passaggi.
Lo scorso 18 settembre, nella fascia oraria dalle 7:00 alle 10:00, oltre 50 tra comuni e aziende che hanno preso parte alla sfida simbolica. Le aziende, in particolare, hanno iscritto i propri dipendenti invitandoli a recarsi al lavoro in bicicletta o con altri mezzi di micromobilità sostenibile. In totale, sono stati registrati 58.455 passaggi attraverso oltre 140 check point distribuiti sul territorio, rilevando gli spostamenti casa-lavoro e casa-scuola effettuati con modalità di trasporto attive e non inquinanti.
La classifica
In vetta alla classifica, conquistando la maglia rosa, con 7.224 passaggi la Città di Padova. New entry, al secondo posto, Pescara (con 6.315 passaggi), che coglie i primi frutti del lavoro di pianificazione fatto in questi anni e che sembra aver intrapreso un percorso virtuoso, lento ma costante, verso la trasformazione dello share modale cittadino. Segue Piacenza (5.621 passaggi), veterana della competizione che risulta prima città nel rapporto rilevamenti/abitanti.
Tra le aziende partecipanti è la Hitachi Rail a trionfare, facendo registrare il maggior numero di ingressi in sede (252) dei dipendenti con sistemi di mobilità attiva. Segue la Agos di Milano con 141. Una menzione speciale alla Angri Eco Servizi di Salerno che si è iscritta alla competizione facendosi promotrice della giornata di mobilità attiva coinvolgendo le scuole e riuscendo a conteggiare, tra studenti e personale scolastico, ben 877 passaggi. Per la categoria “smart working”, Bolzano registra la miglior performance: 72 lavoratori da remoto hanno partecipato da casa grazie al “Check point virtuale”.
Altre città fuori dal podio ma da menzionare per numeri di passaggi sono Ravenna (4.903), Torino (4.116), Milano (4.076), Monza (3.615), Bolzano (3.324), Pesaro (2.303).
Nei prossimi giorni una delegazione del Cigno Verde consegnerà ai vincitori delle due categorie la maglietta rosa.
Differenze tra Nord e Sud Italia
Dalla fotografia scattata grazie all’impegno dei nostri circoli emerge la conferma di un’Italia divisa anche sulle due ruote con una forte disparità nelle adesioni tra i comuni del Centro-Nord e quelli del Sud. Un dislivello che riflette un divario territoriale ben più profondo e strutturale, evidente nella distribuzione della rete ciclabile nazionale: al Nord si contano molte più piste ciclabili, una maggiore densità infrastrutturale, servizi diffusi di bike sharing e soluzioni di micromobilità, nonché una cultura della bicicletta ormai radicata nella vita quotidiana. All’opposto, il Mezzogiorno continua a rimanere indietro, penalizzato da carenze infrastrutturali e scarsa promozione della mobilità sostenibile. Uno scenario già messo in luce dalla nostra  campagna Città2030 , che lo scorso inverno ha fotografato lo stesso squilibrio nei dati raccolti in 17 capoluoghi italiani.
La mobilità sostenibile non è un’utopia
Questa competizione, seppur simbolica, è un forte atto di sensibilizzazione per dimostrare che la mobilità sostenibile è possibile, conveniente e necessaria. Un’occasione per riportare al centro del dibattito pubblico il tema della sicurezza stradale e la vivibilità dello spazio urbano, resa possibile dall’impegno non solo di amministrazioni comunali, ma anche di aziende che scelgono di incentivare i dipendenti a scegliere spostamenti casa-lavoro in bici o in micromobilità, rendendo questa una buona pratica replicabile e vincente. E quanto mai necessaria in un Paese come l’Italia, dove ogni anno oltre 3.000 persone muoiono o restano gravemente ferite a causa della violenza stradale, e dove più di 50.000 morti premature sono causate dall’inquinamento atmosferico. Serve un cambio di paradigma radicale: le città devono diventare spazi a misura di persona, affermando il diritto alla mobilità, alla salute e alla sicurezza. Per questo chiediamo politiche coraggiose, infrastrutture ciclabili diffuse e una nuova cultura urbana che metta al centro chi si muove in modo attivo e sostenibile.
Qui il comunicato stampa

items.title: Raro picchio nero abbattuto a fucilate in Lombardia
items.description:
Ancora un grave atto  di bracconaggio, il WWF denuncia le responsabilità della politica e del mondo venatorio
The post Raro picchio nero abbattuto a f
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il Giaguaro In evidenza Adotta una specie Al CRAS di Valpredina non si è riusciti a salvarlo Un raro picchio nero è stato soccorso ieri dalla Polizia Provinciale di Brescia e trasportato al Centro Recupero Animali Selvatici WWF di Valpredina. L’animale, giunto in condizioni critiche, è risultato colpito da cinque pallini da caccia, come confermato dagli esami radiografici e presentava una frattura all’ala sinistra. Nonostante le cure ricevute, il picchio è morto a causa delle gravi ferite inflitte. Questo episodio non è isolato. In queste prime settimane di stagione venatoria, il CRAS WWF ha già accolto numerosi animali protetti feriti da fucilate, oltre a uccelli sequestrati dalle autorità perché detenuti illegalmente. Una situazione che si ripete ogni anno, in particolare nelle province di Brescia e Bergamo, dove il fenomeno del bracconaggio assume proporzioni allarmanti. Le responsabilità della politica “La responsabilità della politica regionale è evidente e non può più essere taciuta” dichiara Domenico Aiello, responsabile tutela giuridica della Natura per il WWF Italia e componente della Cabina di regia per il contrasto degli illeciti contro gli uccelli selvatici. “Il Consiglio e la Giunta regionale della Lombardia dimenticano di amministrare un territorio con una delle più alte concentrazioni di bracconaggio a livello nazionale e continuano ad approvare provvedimenti richiesti – se non imposti – dalla frangia più estrema del mondo venatorio, che detta legge nella regione.” Nonostante infatti proprio a causa del bracconaggio così esteso e radicato, ogni anno le forze di polizia siano costrette a predisporre nel territorio attività speciali di contrasto a questo fenomeno criminale, in primis l’Operazione “Pettirosso” dei Carabinieri forestali, negli ultimi anni, la Regione ha adottato una serie di misure che, anziché rafforzare i controlli e tutelare la biodiversità, hanno reso sempre più difficile contrastare le illegalità: sanatorie per la detenzione di uccelli da richiamo, la legge nota come “spara e mangia”, l’obbligo per gli agenti di vigilanza di indossare capi ad alta visibilità, e da ultimo la cancellazione del divieto di caccia sui valichi montani, che ha vanificato decenni di battaglie legali e sentenze, anche della Corte costituzionale. E questi sono solo alcuni esempi di una tendenza più ampia e preoccupante che si estende, a livello nazionale, con quanto approvato in questi anni e con il DDL Caccia selvaggia in discussione al Senato. L’impunità del mondo venatorio “Spesso il mondo venatorio si limita a ribadire che caccia e bracconaggio sono due cose diverse, così lavandosene le mani e ignorando del tutto il problema. Ma i dati, soprattutto in Lombardia, dimostrano una stretta correlazione tra la pratica venatoria legale e i fenomeni di illegalità. Questo atteggiamento di disinteresse, condiviso da gran parte di politica e associazioni venatorie, le quali piuttosto che isolare e reprimere, con i fatti, chi persevera in questi deprecabili comportamenti, alimenta un senso di impunità tra chi continua a sparare a qualsiasi cosa si muova, a tappezzare le valli di reti e trappole, a trafficare animali vivi e morti per ottenere profitti illeciti”. Stop caccia selvaggia Firma la petizione WWF che chiede di fermare le leggi contro la natura Aderisci all'appello “La tutela della biodiversità è un diritto di tutti i cittadini e la libertà di vivere in natura non è un privilegio di pochi armati. È tempo che le istituzioni tornino a tutelare l’interesse collettivo anziché piegarsi alle pressioni di chi viola la legge e mette a rischio il patrimonio naturale del Paese” conclude Aiello. Infine un ringraziamento agli operatori del CRAS Valpredina e alle Guardie volontarie per l’impegno profuso.

Dalla fotografia scattata grazie ai lavori dei circoli di Legambiente emerge la conferma di un’Italia divisa anche sulle due ruote con una forte disparità nelle adesioni tra i comuni del Centro-Nord e quelli del Sud. Un dislivello che riflette un divario territoriale ben più profondo e strutturale, evidente nella distribuzione della rete ciclabile nazionale: al Nord si contano molte più piste ciclabili, una maggiore densità infrastrutturale, servizi diffusi di bike sharing e soluzioni di micromobilità, nonché una cultura della bicicletta ormai radicata nella vita quotidiana. All’opposto, il Mezzogiorno continua a rimanere indietro, penalizzato da carenze infrastrutturali e scarsa promozione della mobilità sostenibile. Uno scenario già messo in luce dalla campagna Città2030 di Legambiente, che lo scorso inverno ha fotografato lo stesso squilibrio nei dati raccolti in 17 capoluoghi italiani.

“Questa competizione, seppur simbolica, è un forte atto di sensibilizzazione per dimostrare che la mobilità sostenibile è possibile, conveniente e necessaria – dichiara Roberto Scacchi, responsabile mobilità Legambiente –. Un’occasione per riportare al centro del dibattito pubblico il tema della sicurezza stradale e la vivibilità dello spazio urbano, resa possibile dall’impegno non solo di amministrazioni comunali, ma anche di aziende che scelgono di incentivare i dipendenti a scegliere spostamenti casa-lavoro in bici o in micromobilità, rendendo questa una buona pratica replicabile e vincente. E quanto mai necessaria in un Paese come l’Italia, dove ogni anno oltre 3.000 persone muoiono o restano gravemente ferite a causa della violenza stradale, e dove più di 50.000 morti premature sono causate dall’inquinamento atmosferico. Serve un cambio di paradigma radicale: le città devono diventare spazi a misura di persona, affermando il diritto alla mobilità, alla salute e alla sicurezza. Per questo chiediamo politiche coraggiose, infrastrutture ciclabili diffuse e una nuova cultura urbana che metta al centro chi si muove in modo attivo e sostenibile.”

Altre città fuori dal podio ma da menzionare per numeri di passaggi sono Ravenna (4.903), Torino (4.116), Milano (4.076), Monza (3.615), Bolzano (3.324), Pesaro (2.303).

Nei prossimi giorni una delegazione del Cigno Verde consegnerà ai vincitori delle due categorie la maglietta rosa.

Il Giretto d’Italia è la campagna di Legambiente che da quindici anni scatta un’istantanea delle abitudini di spostamento legate alla mobilità attiva nei capoluoghi del Paese cercando di comprendere come varia il modal share. Rivolta a cittadini, studenti e lavoratori (anche smart worker) ha l’obiettivo di promuovere gli spostamenti casa-lavoro e/o casa-scuola in bici o con l’utilizzo di mezzi di micromobilità elettrica. Per partecipare basta recarsi al lavoro o a scuola utilizzando un mezzo trasporto attivo e non inquinante passando in uno dei check point previsti nelle città aderenti, nella fascia oraria dedicata al monitoraggio. A vincere la sfida è la città/azienda che totalizza il maggior numero di passaggi.
